image.altText: An image of the front of the Adelaide Magistrates Court building on Victoria Square

props.synopsis: Police allege Victorian man Matthew James Dullard struck Orroroo Brevet Sergeant Mark Woods during a traffic stop on the Barrier Highway near Ucolta on Friday.

title.children: Man charged with attempted murder of SA police officer stopped taking medication for diagnosed schizophrenia, court hears

image.altText: A "give way" sign at an intersection on a country road.

props.synopsis: A 51-year-old man facing several charges over a crash at Penola, SA that killed two people has been granted bail and is expected to face court again later this year.

title.children: SA man charged over fatal crash on Easter Sunday granted bail

image.altText: Wes Garrett stands with his arms crossed between two taller firefighters dressed in navy shirts.

props.synopsis: Aviation firefighters are planning to strike over staffing and safety concerns just as thousands of students around Australia are set to begin school holidays.

title.children: Airport firefighters' planned strike action could impact school holiday travel

image.altText: Image of Zomi Frankcom smiling while wearing a cap and a black t-shirt with the WCK logo. Behind her are a lot of kids.

props.synopsis: Gaza medical officials say an Australian working with the World Central Kitchen charity was among a group of people killed by an Israeli air strike in central Gaza.

title.children: Australian aid worker Zomi Frankcom killed by apparent Israeli air strike

image.altText: Two women smile excitedly for a selfie.

props.synopsis: A friend and former colleague of killed Australian aid worker Zomi Frankcom says the world has lost a "great helper" after several charity workers in Gaza die in a reported Israeli air strike.

title.children: Killed Australian aid worker's friend says Zomi Frankcom was 'relentless and huge-hearted'

image.altText: the Royal Adelaide Hospital sign on the front of the building with a tree in the foreground.

props.synopsis: Ambulance ramping at South Australia's public hospitals reached near-record levels last month, with the state government citing "extreme" pressure on the health system.

title.children: SA ambulance ramping hits near-record levels amid 'extreme' pressure on the system

image.altText: A 'sold' sticker being placed on a 'for auction' sign outside a house.

props.synopsis: Terms like negative gearing and capital gains tax sound complicated but you shouldn't be put off by the financial jargon. You don't need to be a money expert to understand what they mean.

title.children: What is negative gearing? Why is it so controversial?

image.altText: Jace Reh looks.

props.synopsis: Gay conversion practices have been outlawed across much of the country, most recently in New South Wales — but not in South Australia. Jace Reh is one of several survivors involved in an SA group that is pushing for a ban.

title.children: Advocates call for end to 'harmful' gay conversion practices in South Australia

image.altText: A resort swimming pool

props.synopsis: Australia's Sikh community is offering support for the family of fathers Dharmvir and Gurjinder Singh, who drowned while trying to save a toddler who slipped into a hotel pool on the weekend.

title.children: 'You think this couldn't happen': Community rallies around family who lost two fathers in hotel pool drowning

image.altText: An Uber sticker in the back window of a red car

props.synopsis: The tech giant admitted it operated its UberX app at a time when peer-to-peer ridesharing was illegal in some Australian states.

title.children: 'I want to destroy them': Court examines Uber's conduct as the tech giant gained a foothold in Australian market

image.altText: Wires and components inside the Opal nuclear research reactor.

props.synopsis: For decades, Australians have been hesitant to embrace nuclear power – but there are signs attitudes might be shifting as younger Australians see climate change as their generation's existential threat.

title.children: The US and Japan have 'tripled down on nuclear', could it be time for Australia to shift its attitude?

image.altText: A close up of Trump speaking.

props.synopsis: The former US president was found liable on February 16 for fraudulently inflating his net worth by billions of dollars to secure better loan and insurance terms.

title.children: Trump posts $269 million bond to avoid asset seizures

image.altText: a sign over a cement building that reads google in white

props.synopsis: Google agrees to purge millions of Chrome users' personal data as part of a settlement in a lawsuit accusing the online search giant of illegal surveillance.

title.children: Google to purge billions of files containing Chrome users' personal data

image.altText: Composite image of a young man taking into a mic, a blond woman looking into the camera and young woman with black hair singing

props.synopsis: From a new episode of Quiet on Set to JoJo Siwa’s edgy new look, here’s what you missed in entertainment over the long weekend.

title.children: Rebel Wilson slams Fat Pizza and Grimsby co-star ahead of memoir drop, and more entertainment news

image.altText: Man and woman, married couple, stand in their garden in front of a steel frame garden feature.

props.synopsis: These television towers, and their quirky histories, live on in some towns in the Mid North and Yorke Peninsula in South Australia despite the analogue signal ending in Australia in 2013.

title.children: Old TV towers now a unique garden feature

image.altText: A man in handcuffs and a prison jumpsuit wipes tears from his eyes

props.synopsis: Alex Murdaugh is serving two life sentences for killing his wife and son — his latest sentencing means a successful appeal likely won't set him free.

title.children: Convicted killer Alex Murdaugh sentenced to 40 years in prison for financial crimes

image.altText: A teenager with a brown bob speaks into a megaphone

props.synopsis: When you come of age in Israel, you are expected to serve in the military. But for some young citizens, they have decided to risk the rejection of their families and time in prison rather than join the fight in Gaza.

title.children: As her dad watched on, 18yo Sofia told the IDF she could not fight in Gaza. Then she went to jail

image.altText: From the ground up, a large brown brick apartment complex stands, with a cloudy blue sky backdrop.

props.synopsis: Many strata managers know that in the long absence of proper regulation by government, the industry has become addicted to the routine exploitation of apartment owners and the easy profits that flow as a result.

title.children: We asked for stories about strata management. The deluge of responses describes an industry rife with suspect practices

image.altText: Two volunteers wearing Yes and No campaign shirts stand next to each other with their faces cropped out.

props.synopsis: Yes campaign groups spent more than twice as much as No campaign groups during the referendum, according to new figures from the Australian Electoral Commission.

title.children: Referendum disclosures: Yes comfortably outspends No, but No expenditure opaque

image.altText: An aerial view of a large newly built house in an estate with an open two car garage and green lawns.

props.synopsis: New data shows landlords are buying every third property that hits the market, as house values continue to grow. Some experts say it's keeping house prices out of reach for young people and first home buyers.

title.children: Landlords 'over-represented' in property market as house prices rise for 14th straight month

image.altText: Some weeds on a dune at a beach at sunset

props.synopsis: Esperance Police say the body is in "an extremely difficult position" within a rock formation off the coast of Cape Arid.

title.children: Police recovering body believed to be missing fisherman off WA's southern coast

image.altText: People walking along a street in Tokyo lined with Japanese flags.

props.synopsis: Japan spent years as an economic powerhouse before spending decades under threat from recessions. But seemingly overnight, its fortunes appear to have changed — and it could provide a glimpse into the future for us all.

title.children: Why the sun is rising on a new Japanese dawn

image.altText: A stock market watcher stands in front of an ASX board.

props.synopsis: The ASX 200 has ended lower at the end of its first session for the week after the four-day Easter break, while the RBA published its minutes of its most recent interest rates meeting.

title.children: ASX ends lower after hitting new record high, meeting minutes reveal RBA's 'Goldilocks' approach for March interest rates meeting — as it happened

image.altText: Bruce Lehrmann smiles while walking outside court, wearing a suit and tie and glasses.

props.synopsis: Today, Network Ten will ask the Federal Court to consider new evidence in Bruce Lehrmann's defamation case over coverage of Brittany Higgins's rape allegation — the judgment for which was to be delivered on Thursday.

title.children: Network Ten's application to introduce new evidence in Bruce Lehrmann's defamation could delay judgment

image.altText: Snowtown accomplice Mark Ray Haydon in a car being escorted from court.

props.synopsis: The chair of SA's parole board says it is "concerning" that Snowtown bodies-in-the-barrels accomplice Mark Haydon is being prevented from adjusting to life in the community, despite being granted parole.

title.children: Snowtown accomplice Mark Haydon still in custody despite being granted parole

image.altText: A woman with brown hair and glasses smiles while crouching next to pot plants

props.synopsis: Christine Lyness is being remembered as a dedicated mother and nursing assistant after the Easter Sunday crash in regional Queensland.

title.children: Community pays tribute to aged care worker killed in crash with car allegedly stolen from charity

image.altText: Katy Gallagher

props.synopsis: Federal politicians could have their pay docked by up to five per cent for serious breaches of workplace rules, under draft laws set to be considered by parliament.

title.children: New rules for federal MPs could see politicians have their pay docked for misbehaving

image.altText: Two skiers on snow with a large mountain in the distance.

props.synopsis: Three people are killed and another is injured in an avalanche at Riffelberg, near the Swiss Alpine ski resort of Zermatt.

title.children: Three killed in avalanche near Swiss resort

image.altText: A middle-aged Indigenous woman with dyed red hair looks at the camera with a neutral expression.

props.synopsis: An Aboriginal elder who recently worked for NT Police is among a group of Aboriginal Territorians calling for more to be done to address racism within the force.

title.children: Aboriginal elder calls for NT Police unit to apologise to community over 'disgraceful' award

image.altText: Andrew Giles stands next to Clare O'Neil at a press conference

props.synopsis: Labor senators have joined the chorus of criticism of the federal government’s unsuccessful attempt to ram contentious immigration legislation through parliament last week, arguing the bill was so serious that it needed proper scrutiny.

title.children: Labor senators join criticism of the government's rushed immigration legislation

image.altText: Dark storm clouds gather over a beach in Victoria as people walk along the sand.

props.synopsis: A cold front moving through Victoria, New South Wales and Tasmania is expected to be followed by heavy rain, storms and potentially the first east coast low for 2024.

title.children: A band of rain and storms is sweeping across south-eastern states ahead of a more significant weather event

image.altText: A woman with black hair looks to the sky, with people either side of her.

props.synopsis: When Nadene Dodd's teenage son was locked up in juvenile detention, it was meant to keep him and the community safe, but instead he lost his life. Six months on, a coronial inquest is due to begin the search for answers to the tragedy.

title.children: Cleveland Dodd died in the WA government's care at 16 and now his mother wants answers

image.altText: Man standing in the water holding a box jellyfish with his bare hands

props.synopsis: A mysterious and excruciating illness was striking down beachgoers in North Queensland until the 1960s, when a doctor and a "puny little boy" went to extraordinary lengths to solve the mystery.

title.children: The jellyfish detective who discovered the Irukandji by stinging volunteers — including his 10-year-old son

image.altText: A  stainless steel sink full of dirty coffee cups and dishes, with a dish rack and glasses on the left-hand side.

props.synopsis: Although most people don't deliberately set out to show disregard for their co-workers, poor hygiene practices can take a toll on the physical health and mental wellbeing of employees.

title.children: What a dirty office kitchen says about your workplace (and possibly you, too)

image.altText: havana embassy

props.synopsis: The Kremlin has dismissed a report that Russian military intelligence may be behind the mysterious "Havana syndrome" ailment that has afflicted US diplomats and spies globally.

title.children: Investigation links mystery 'spy' illness to Russian intelligence
